awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Supports and Challenges in an Educational Crisis: The Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Youth STEM Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Across the country, educators and mentors in informal settings have provided youth with opportunities to persist and thrive along STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) trajectories. Unfortunately, the current COVID-19 pandemic may limit youths’ opportunities to continue pursuing STEM pathways by removing their access to important resources, such as mentors in science labs and other STEM learning spaces. The impact of the pandemic may be especially harmful for youth from underrepresented groups whose families have been disproportionately affected by this crisis. The purpose of this project is to study the impact of COVID-19 on the STEM trajectories of teenagers from underrepresented groups who had previously worked with scientists as mentors before the pandemic. A survey, which will be administered to hundreds of teenagers, will identify the supports that they used to successfully navigate disruptions as they continued to pursue college and career pathways in STEM. For teenagers who decided not to actively pursue STEM pathways during the pandemic, this survey will illuminate how loss of supports and new challenges discouraged their active pursuit of STEM. By identifying supports and challenges that encouraged or discouraged STEM pursuits, this project will advance knowledge on how informal learning programs can support underrepresented teenagers in persisting along STEM pathways during national crises and emergencies.

The American Museum of Natural History will conduct mixed-methods research to explore the impact of the pandemic on the STEM trajectories of underrepresented teenagers. They will administer surveys to 560 teenagers from underrepresented groups who previously participated in the New York City Science Research Mentoring Consortium. The survey will ascertain whether and how the youth found access to new supports or lost access to former supports; whether they face new challenges and how they have responded to those challenges; and whether and how their feelings about pursuing STEM in college and beyond have changed. Teenagers who complete the survey will identify adults in their lives who have been important in supporting their pursuits in STEM, and two adults per teenager will also be invited to complete surveys on perceived disruptions. Latent class analyses, cognitive interviews, and consultation with youth and survey experts will be used to establish survey validity, while the survey results will be analyzed via two-mode social network analysis. Additionally, 16 teenagers will participate in in-depth interviews regarding the impact of the pandemic on their STEM trajectories. Findings and implications for practice will be disseminated widely to researchers, educators, and mentors in informal science education. These findings will help stakeholders to provide better supports for underrepresented youth during the current pandemic and during future national emergencies. This project is funded by the Advanced Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program. As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the AISL program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Undeniably, the pandemic dramatically impacted the lives of college and university students. Our study focused on 190 college students who participated in a mentored science research program while in high school and have been participants in a longitudinally study focused on tracking pathways in STEM. Our study questions were 1) What is the impact of the educational disruptions and loss of opportunities due to the pandemic upon the trajectories of youth who are historically underrepresented in science? 2) What types of supports and resources did youth draw upon to mitigate these disruptions as they formulated new plans and made decisions about their academic and professional pursuits? To center youth voices, draw on youth standpoints, and support the trustworthiness and credibility of our findings, we have established a cohort of youth to serve as co-researchers for the duration of the longitudinal study. Two alumni co-researchers were attending college at the time of the study and brought their perspectives and experiences as students pursuing degrees and making key decisions regarding their future plans with respect to graduate school during campus shutdowns and remote learning requirements. They supported the design and pilot-testing of our surveys and interview guides, provided important guidance around the timing of our surveys in light of the pressures facing students at different times of the academic year, conducted analysis of survey data, and co-authored findings disseminated in reports and online publications. Our methods included surveys at two points in the academic year 2020-2021, interviews with a subset of 26 students and surveys of faculty named by participants as being supportive during the pandemic.

 

We found three types of impact of the educational disruptions on students? academic trajectories. The first category of impact is related to isolation and mental health. Campus shutdowns and living conditions during quarantine contributed to an increased sense of isolation, had the largest impact on students? academic and personal motivation and impeded students? ability to create community and a sense of belonging. This was particularly true for students of color based on patterns from our interview data. Students who lived at home with family during campus shutdowns struggled to be productive and balance their academic responsibilities with their expectations of their families.

 

The second category of impact was related to the learning environment. The pedagogical and technical approaches that faculty espoused in virtual courses had a big impact on whether participants had access to individualized support, something they felt was necessary for their success. Participants shared the need for faculty to understand that attending college during the pandemic meant shifting one?s expectations for learning experiences, particularly for virtual learning environments.

 

The third category of impact was related to participants reporting that the pandemic affected their academic decisions in college and challenged their ability to complete their degrees; this was particularly critical for STEM students. They experienced a loss of engagement in STEM practices and collaborative work due to campus closures and online courses. Limited access to in-person lab and internship opportunities hindered students' abilities to gain hands-on experiences, get exposure to new scientific practices, and develop their expertise on particular practices of science that might provide them with important decision-making experiences for their graduate school and career goals. For some students majoring in STEM, the challenges of remote learning in courses requiring computational thinking and mathematical problem-solving were particularly difficult in virtual learning environments and resulted in students delaying and/or avoiding these courses during the pandemic. Overall, our study participants have in large part persisted with their interest in pursuing STEM careers with over 78% continuing to pursue a STEM major. However, there were several participants who switched from one type of STEM major to another STEM major, such as switching from physics to public health, because of the challenges the pandemic posed to their academic and personal goals. A small subset of participants switched out of being a STEM major entirely, but we don?t have enough evidence to know if it was due to the pandemic. 

 

There were several supports and resources participants drew upon to mitigate the obstacles they faced during the pandemic. Friends and peers were identified as the most utilized source for both academic and personal/social support for students during the pandemic, followed by parents, family members, and faculty.  The next support group was composed of academic advisors, research advisors, and faculty as significant individuals who provided academic resources during the pandemic. Participants also shared that as the pandemic continued, their academic institutions modified policies to reflect flexibility, compassion and individualized support.

 

Based on these patterns, we have developed a list of recommendations for college students, college faculty and deans and presidents of higher education institutions. A more detailed report and the associated recommendations can be found at bit.ly/3MsZyp7.
